awd_titl_txt: SHF:  Small:  Collaborative Research:  Uncovering Vulnerabilities in Parallel File Systems for Reliable High Performance Computing
awd_abstract_narration:
Many scientific problems (e.g., computational biology, high-energy physics, climate science) rely on high performance computing (HPC) systems to manage and process massive amounts of data. However, with the rapid increase in scale and complexity, even the specially-designed and well-maintained HPC platforms may fail. This research aims to design innovative methodologies that scrutinize parallel file systems, the major storage software which empowers HPC platforms, and uncover the issues in parallel file systems that can lead to data loss under various failure scenarios. Such an effort is a fundamental step towards building highly reliable HPC systems and meet the demand of data-driven scientific discovery. In addition, this project integrates the research activities with education and outreach efforts to train broadly inclusive and globally competitive science workforce.

More specifically, this project includes two synergistic research tasks, which enables automatic testing as well as diagnosing the issues in parallel file systems. The first task focuses on testing parallel file systems through a single-fault injection framework, which interrupts the normal workloads of the target parallel file system automatically, and examines if the interruption could lead to any issues that cannot be fixed by the corresponding checker of the parallel file system. Building on the first task, the second task focuses on diagnosing the issues uncovered in the previous task through a two-level provenance-based analysis. The first level analysis builds the coarse-grain, inter-node provenance, which provides a high-level picture of the entire system behavior. The second level analysis creates the fine-grain, intra-node provenance that contains causal paths within each individual node. In addition, multiple provenance traces are aligned and compared automatically to help locate the problematic code region with minimal human efforts.

por.por_cntn:
This project supported Texas Tech University, a public state university and a Hispanic Serving Institution in west Texas, to conduct forward-looking research to understand vulnerabilities of parallel file systems, the major software component powering high performance computing (HPC) systems. The research findings help build more reliable HPC systems. Since many scientific problems, such as computational biology, high-energy physics, climate science, computational chemistry, rely on HPC systems to manage and process massive amounts of data, this research contributes to improving the productivity of scientific computing too. Additionally, many undergraduate and graduate students were trained throughout this project either directly via participating in this project or indirectly via courses and activities offered. This project contributed to both new knowledge discovery and the workforce development for the nation and our society. 

Intellectual Merit: This research delivered in-depth understandings about file system vulnerabilities and created new methodologies for mitigating the impact of vulnerabilities and failures. First, we analyzed representative parallel file systems in detail. These analyses provided insights about the root causes of the problems observed. We also used tracing tools and collected events in the system to further analyze the vulnerabilities. Second, we developed new solutions, including failure recovery, logging, and emulation mechanisms to overcome the impact of vulnerabilities and failures. Third, we developed other advanced solutions, including data distribution optimization, storage layout characterization, and failure prediction to further overcome the problems. Last, we also investigated the resource usage and application behaviors of production HPC systems and the impact of failed workloads. These findings help system administrators identify areas of improvement. The research results have been disseminated via more than 10 publications, with many of them published in top venues in the field, such as IEEE Transactions on Computers, ACM Transactions on Storage, ACM/IEEE Supercomputing Conference, International Conference on Supercomputing, etc. These publications, along with open-source code repositories, disseminated the research findings developed throughout this project to the broad community.

Broader Impacts: The results of this research will help build more reliable high performance computing systems. Since high performance computing remains a strategic tool for scientific discovery, this research contributes to improving the scientific computing productivity and has broad impacts. Students received intense training and professional development throughout this project. Specifically, two doctoral students and ten undergraduate and Master students have graduated with the support of this project. Under-represented minority students such as women and Hispanic students were particularly trained throughout this project too. This project has educated and delivered globally competitive workforce for the nation and our society.
